My Info Payment method
Maximum tabs
Each Tabs instance can have maximum 8 tabs.
Tab 01 Tab02 Tab03 Tab04 Ta >
When to use
We use tabs to group and allow navigation between related content at the same level of
the hierarchy.
Tabs can be used to organise content such as forms, settings or a dashboard.
When not to use
We do not use Tabs for primary navigation. If a Tab structure becomes too complex,
consider using a standard navigation pattern.
Tabs should not be used to indicate progress.
Tabs vs. Segmented Control
Tabs and Segmented Control are similar components as they enable users to switch
between views or content sections without leaving the page or interface. However, the
two components have some key differences that should determine which component
you should use in your context.
Account Billing Settings
Use Tabs for navigating between different sections of information, each with its own Use Segmented Control when you need to switch between related content views
content or functionality. For instance, “Account,” “Billing,” and “Settings” in a (web)app. within a context. For instance, toggling between “Grid view” and “List view.”
Tabs vs. Pills
Use Tabs when you need to structure and navigate information in a page specific
context, or where it's important for the user to stay on the same page.
Tabs work as page navigation placed at the top of the page or region, which switches
the content of an entire page or region beneath it. Pills can be placed wherever on the
page and do not necessarily switch the content below it. Pills can have other item
attributes attached to it, such as opening a modal.
I 1Twvill.
Filter
My Info Payment method
Kitchens Bathrooms Outdoors
Tabs used on profile page where the content are page specific. Pills used to navigate to different pages.
Tabs vs. Accordions
Tabs are generally more navigational than Accordions. Tabs allow the user to see their
current position amongst the other available options.
Tabs switch the content of an entire region or page. They are useful for organising
related content into distinct views. Accordions generally should only expand a short
distance to progressively reveal additional information.
For scenarios where there are many tabs or the number of tabs is an unknown quantity,
an Accordion at full width is a safe bet. Single-column layouts are responsive regardless
of content quantity.
Profile
My Info Payment method
— My info v
Payment methods v
Tabs are always placed at the top of a page or the region where it belongs to. Accordions can be placed anywhere on the page and are a useful way to gather large
amounts information.
Pre-select an option
Tabs always need to be pre-selected. Not having a pre-selected tab can make users feel
lost when they can’t navigate back to its default state.
Support Support
Delivery Service Returns Guaran > Delivery Service Returns Guaran >
SE
@ Providing a pre-selected state and helping users quickly understand where they © Not providing a pre-selected and making it difficult for users to return to its default
are in the tab navigation. state.
Tabs placement
Users scan pages from top to bottom, which is why Tabs are always placed at the top of
the page. It's easier to understand that content is placed inside a tab when it's located
under the tab.
Support
Delivery Service Returns Guaran >
Delivery Service Returns Guaran >
@ Q A o ue
SE
@ Tabs placed at the top of a UL. © Tabs placed at the bottom of a UI.
Short tab titles
Tab titles should be clear, short and similar in length across the entire grouping of tabs.
This makes them easy to scan.
Support Support
Delivery Service Returns Guaran > When do | receive my package? Service >
LL ee, J
@ Tabs with similar title lengths that are easy to scan. © Tabs with long and varying title lengths that are more difficult to scan.

Tab selector
The Tab selector slides horizontally between the selected tab
after being activated.

Keyboard interactions
Key Description
Tab Focuses the first selected Tab within the Tab bar. The user can press tab again to move focus to next element in the page
Tab.
Left Arrow Moves focus to the previous Tab item. If focus is on the first Tab item, it moves focus to the last Tab in the Tab bar.
Right Arrow Moves focus to the next Tab item. If focus is on the last Tab, it moves focus to the first Tab in the Tab bar.
Enter / Space Activates the Tab or arrow that is in focus.
